hits._id: Government acquisition of Neville Fernando Hospital takes place with the signing of the agreement

Health officials, members of Armed Forces etc will take part in this programme. Special attention will be paid to schools.
Dr. Mahipala pointed out that people should seek prompt medical treatment from a state hospital, if they suffer from any type of fever for more than two days. Prompt medical treatment obtained from a state hospital can save lives, because dengue patients can avoid serious complications such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) and Dengue Shock Syndrome by seeking medical treatment without delay.
Patients suffering from fever should only take paracetamol and should refrain from taking any other medications or pain killers. Other medications can lead to complications such as internal bleeding, if the patient is suffering from dengue fever.

hits._id: Another successful heart transplant in Kandy

_source.content:
A group of medical specialists at the Kandy Teaching Hospital’s Cardiology and Cardiothoracic Unit has conducted the second successful heart transplant to be conducted in Sri Lanka.
The operation, which was started at around 8pm yesterday (26), concluded at 5am today.
The recipient of the heart was 19-year-old, Sachini Sewwandhi, a resident of Kaluwa Modera, Aluthgama.
The Director of Kandy Teaching Hospital, Dr. Samantha Ratnayake said Sewwandhi's heart was functioning only 10% when specialists decided to conduct a heart transplant.
The group of doctors, led by Heart Specialist Dr. Anil Abeywickrema, conducted the surgery.
Dr. Ratnayake said it was the same group who conducted the country’s first ever heart transplant, two months ago, took part in this transplant operation also.
Sewwandhi’s father, Chaminda Mahesh Kumara, who is a driver by profession said his eldest daughter died 7 years ago due to a heart ailment.
According to him, Sewwandhi has been suffering from a heart ailment for the last six years and they did their utmost to secure her life.
Then they have decided to meet Dr. Ratnayake at the Kandy Teaching Hospital and he had referred Sewwandi to Heart Specialist, Dr. Anil Abeywickrema. 
Sewwandhi’s mother, Priyanka Nilmini said she stayed at the hospital with her daughter since March this year, hoping that doctors would help them save their child.
She also expressed their gratitude to the parents of the youth who died at the hospital, for agreeing to donate the heart of the youth to be transplanted to Sewwandhi.
She is now kept at the ICU with close medical attention, the Director of the Kandy Teaching Hospital, Dr. Ratnayake said.The donor was Nalinda Sakalasuriya, who had died in a road accident, at Haragama on 21st of this month.
 His father told us, most of the organs of Nalinda were donated to be transplanted.

_source.content:
Health authorities say 13 persons including 11 children have died from a viral fever spreading in the Southern Province.
 
Southern Province health authorities say that the fever is caused by influenza virus along with the Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.
 
Earlier, 5 children died at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital and 3 of them were affected by influenza and other 2 had infected with the Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.

The health authorities say pregnant mothers and small children are more prone to this disease.
 
They urge the public to seek medical advice if fever persists more than one day.

hits._id: Gold Coins found in Condoms

_source.content:
A Sri Lankan individual who landed in Kochi airport was admitted to the Government Medical College, Ernakulam, on Monday after he attempted to smuggle gold into the country by swallowing it.
He showed signs of uneasiness, which raised suspicion among officials. They initially thought he had concealed gold nuggets in rectum, a common ploy of smugglers, but he later confessed to swallowing gold coins. He was shifted to the hospital after he complained of weakness. Officials said one gold coin was removed from his stomach at the hospital.
Hospital sources said the person had swallowed 13 gold coins, wrapped in condoms. “We put him through X-ray and ultrasound scans and spotted the coins. His condition is stable but it can turn worse if the remaining coins get stuck in the stomach,” they stated.
Customs officials have recovered two gold bars and a chain from the Sri Lankan national's possession. (The Hindu)
